[Burke]: Since the pandemic method made it a priority to support all students with enough educators and programs in the schools to address their needs.

[Burke]: These cuts will not allow for these programs and teachers to continue to provide this support, the message tech school will be impacted the most by these cuts which also includes the therapeutic learning program as well as the newcomers.

[Burke]: We can all agree that the early elementary years are very important years that as we are building these necessary foundational skills for learning in life.

[Burke]: Mr. Russo.

[Burke]: Make motions now.

[Burke]: Normally, new business would be on the agenda.

[Burke]: And then the motion would be sent somewhere so that everyone has an opportunity to know what the topic is.

[Burke]: OK.

[Burke]: Can we suspend the rules so that we can hear our colleagues' motions?

[Burke]: Open meeting law to me, it's open meeting law.

[Burke]: If you want to object to my ruling, feel free.

[Burke]: It's an open meeting law.

[Burke]: Generally, you have things on the agenda written clearly so the public knows what you're going to talk about.

[Burke]: So if they want to be here to talk about it, they have ample opportunity to.

[Burke]: That's the purpose of open meeting law.

[Burke]: That's all.

[Burke]: You just have to put it on.

[Burke]: Well, you could write it that way.

[Burke]: You could make your motion in that form that I'd like to offer this topic be sent to the subcommittee on rules or whatever it is.

[Burke]: So you could put it in there so it's clear that that's your purpose.

[Burke]: Or it could go to subcommittee right out.

[Burke]: Subcommittee can have a meeting on any topic and they post the meeting, the topic, and then people can come to that.

[Burke]: Right.

[Burke]: It can go there, start there, and the work could be done there, and then it comes to the floor.

[Burke]: Either way.

[Burke]: OK.

[Burke]: for future generations.

[Burke]: The Medford School Committee recognizes Mr. Moran's outstanding leadership as the executive director of the Friends of the Fells Reservation.

[Burke]: By his own example, Ron demonstrates how to enjoy and protect our natural resources and in turn our quality of life.

[Burke]: Through his generosity of time and spirit given to the citizens of Medford and the visitors of the Middlesex Fells Reservation, Ron teaches us to value and protect those resources which sustain and inspire us.

[Burke]: Mr. Moran,

[Burke]: He's the outgoing chair.

[Burke]: And so we didn't want this moment to go by without paying a tribute to you, because you were so instrumental in protecting the 90 millimeter site, which for those of us in Medford realize it could have been a hockey rink had others had their way.

[Burke]: So I wanted to personally thank you, and I know that it's so important.

[Burke]: Ms.

[Burke]: Glennon was the mother of Columbus School occupational therapist Celeste Krause.

[Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of James F. Davideo.

[Burke]: Mr. Davideo taught for 33 years in the Medford Public Schools, first at the Lincoln Junior High, and then at the McGlynn Middle School.

[Burke]: Also under suspension as the Medford School Committee expresses sincere condolences to the family of Joseph Grandy.

[Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Salvatore Caraviello.

[Burke]: Mr. Caraviello was the uncle of Medford City Councilor Richard Caraviello.

[Burke]: Also be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Elizabeth Irving.

[Burke]: Ms.

[Burke]: Irving was the mother of McGlynn Middle School math teacher Robin Irving.

[Burke]: She passed away June 22 at the age of 93 years old.

[Burke]: A lifelong resident of West Medford, she was the mother of six girls who all graduated from Medford High School.

[Burke]: Robin Irving, the father of Robin, passed away January 4, 2016 at the age of 88 years old.

[Burke]: Could we please all rise for a moment of silence on the passing of... Thank you.

[Burke]: Also, we have a long resolution.

[Burke]: To hold harmless 2019 10th grade MCAS due to racist question.

[Burke]: Whereas, the graduation requirement makes the 10th grade MCAS exam one of the highest stakes exams most Massachusetts students take.

[Burke]: Whereas, teachers, families, schools, and tax payers all invest time and resources to give students the best possible chance at success on the exam.

[Burke]: Whereas, the recent 10th grade MCAS English exam contained an essay that required students to write a journal entry from the perspective of an openly racist character.

[Burke]: And whereas, the Mass Deci

[Burke]: was unable to defend the question, quickly moving to not have it count.

[Burke]: And whereas we only discovered this because students had the courage to violate the rules about discussing specific MCAS questions.

[Burke]: And whereas research shows that exposure to negative stereotypes can have a negative impact on student performance.

[Burke]: And whereas the impact of the racist question on performance cannot be quantified.

[Burke]: Now, therefore, be it resolved that the Medford School Committee calls on DESE to exempt students who took the test with the rejected question from the graduation exam requirement, and further that the Medford School Committee calls for DESE to immediately implement a policy of releasing old MCAS questions so that there can be transparency to prevent such egregious errors in the future, and further resolved that a copy of this resolution be delivered to DESE, the governor, and the Medford state and local legislative delegations, and otherwise widely distributed.

[Burke]: Mr. Russo, on the motion?

[Burke]: Motion to approve.

[Burke]: Item two, report on the science of dyslexia.

[Burke]: Dr. Nadine Gabb.

[Burke]: Gabb, I'm sorry.

[Burke]: Good evening.

[Burke]: While that's being set up, I would like to read a biography on Dr. Gabb.

[Burke]: Dr. Gabb is an associate professor of pediatrics at Boston Children's Hospital and the Harvard Medical School.

[Burke]: She received her PhD in psychology from the University of Zurich in Switzerland and did post-doctoral training at Stanford University and MIT.

[Burke]: Her research with the laboratories of cognitive neuroscience focuses on the development of typical and atypical language and literary skills, as well as pre-markers of learning disabilities.

[Burke]: More specifically, she works on the identification of possible pre-markers of reading disabilities, including developmental dyslexia.

[Burke]: In the pre-reading and infant brain, the identification of the underlying neural mechanism of comorbidity of developmental dyslexia and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

[Burke]: and the development of tablet-based technology for early screening approaches for learning disabilities.

[Burke]: Her lab works closely with over 50 private and public schools nationwide, and she's a frequent speaker in the community.

[Burke]: She's the 2019 recipient of the LDA Award, Learning Disabilities Association of America Award, and in 2018, Dr. Gabb was presented with the Alan C. Crocker Award for her advocacy on behalf of children with dyslexia and reading disabilities and efforts around the recent passage

[Burke]: of the Massachusetts Screening Legislation.

[Burke]: She has also been recognized by the International Dyslexia Association in receipt of the Alice H. Garside Award for Outstanding Leadership in Advancing the Science and Advocacy of Dyslexia.

[Burke]: She is further a recipient of the T. Barry Brazelton Award for Innovation at Boston's Children's Hospital.

[Burke]: She's a scientific advisory board member of the Dyslexia Foundation and Landmark School and a founder of the New England Research on Dyslexia Society.

[Burke]: This is a historic day, a day that has been long in the coming.

[Burke]: Welcome to the groundbreaking of the Medford Police Headquarters.

[Burke]: This headquarters represents a new era in policing in Medford.

[Burke]: This station is critical to 21st century policing model that our offices embody.

[Burke]: It took perseverance by many to make this happen.

[Burke]: Many with us today, so thank you all.

[Burke]: This new facility will improve readiness and morale and will compliment the dedication the members of the Medford Police Department demonstrate daily.

[Burke]: It will permit these committed men and women to come to work in a building that they are proud of each and every day.

[Burke]: This groundbreaking ceremony is an exciting first step in the legacy of the Medford Police Department and our service to the residents of Medford.

[Burke]: The state-of-the-art facility will be a beacon of safety for our community for years to come.

[Burke]: So thank you, thank you, thank you, all of you.

[Burke]: So I'd like to introduce our district attorney, Marion Ryan.

[Burke]: So we all know that it takes many to get the job done.

[Burke]: And I want to recognize some of the team within City Hall that has been working on this project for the last two and a half years.

[Burke]: And there are more than I'm going to name, but these are the key people.

[Burke]: Of course, Chief Sacco.

[Burke]: Chief Sacco fought every day to make this happen, knowing he would not be chief when the building is completed.

[Burke]: He knew how important it was for the members of the Medford Police Department.

[Burke]: Thank you to Chief Sacco.

[Burke]: And of course Chief Buckley who stepped up, carried the reins.

[Burke]: I don't think we skipped a beat.

[Burke]: We just continued to have our weekly meetings and instead of Chief Sacco we had Chief Buckley present.

[Burke]: So thank you Chief Buckley also for jumping right in and

[Burke]: keeping the process moving.

[Burke]: We have our city solicitor Mark Rumley who I believe is here today.

[Burke]: Mark has been through every step of this process and he has been our confidant and he has kept us moving and always

[Burke]: how to do everything the right way.

[Burke]: So thank you, Mark.

[Burke]: Jen Deverwood, Chief of Staff.

[Burke]: She's in on all the weekly meetings and she has definitely kept us moving.

[Burke]: She keeps everybody informed and makes sure that the process is on target and on date.

[Burke]: Annmarie Irwin, our treasurer.

[Burke]: Where would we be without the money, right?

[Burke]: So Annmarie's been watching the dollars, watching the cash flow, and she makes sure that everything happens right.

[Burke]: So she's been an integral part of this process.

[Burke]: Paul Mokia, Building Commissioner and his team.

[Burke]: You've looked at every plan.

[Burke]: You gave guidance.

[Burke]: You gave advice.

[Burke]: So you have made this a better project.

[Burke]: So thank you, Paul and the team in the building department.

[Burke]: Alicia Hunt, as we all know, she's actually in Boston today.

[Burke]: Her office has been at the meetings regularly and has made sure that this building is built to our 21st century standards from an energy perspective, environmental perspective.

[Burke]: And I think you can see the pile behind us.

[Burke]: We had to let that wait for about six, seven months because we're building up the site.

[Burke]: Because in 50 years, we don't know where the Mystic River is going to end up.

[Burke]: And we wanted to protect our investment.

[Burke]: So we spent the time in order to make this site be about four feet, four feet, am I correct?

[Burke]: Four feet taller, higher.

[Burke]: four feet higher.

[Burke]: So thank you Alicia Hunt for all the work you've done and also Shab Khan from our procurement office.

[Burke]: Shab has made sure everything has been ticked and tied and done correctly so according to the law.

[Burke]: So thank you Shab from our team.

[Burke]: We of course have the members of the Medford Police Department that went and visited many sites

[Burke]: They saw some new stations, some not so new stations.

[Burke]: They tried to pick the best of what they saw.

[Burke]: And I think that when we open up this building, you're going to see that this is a beautiful building.

[Burke]: It's an efficient building, and it will work for the benefit of the men and women of our Medford Police Department.

[Burke]: And a man that I'm going to introduce up next, Jeff Shaw.

[Burke]: Jeff Shaw has been with us for the last seven years.

[Burke]: I know he's going to elaborate in his words, but he's been with us since we started doing the space needs assessment.

[Burke]: And Jeff has been a partner.

[Burke]: And if I told you he's looked at 10 sites for us, that's probably an understatement.

[Burke]: Whenever I had an idea, or if I drove by a vacant lot, or I drove by a building, I'd say, hey, Jeff, what do you think?

[Burke]: Can you go, can you fit a police station on that, number one?

[Burke]: And what would it look like?

[Burke]: in the surroundings.

[Burke]: And Jeff has done more than one big sketch for us to see if we could find a perfect location.

[Burke]: And it wasn't until an officer that I won't name came by and visited my office and he said, have you looked at the training center?

[Burke]: And I'm like, you guys use the training center.

[Burke]: And he was like, that'd be a perfect location, because we like being right here.

[Burke]: We like this location.

[Burke]: We like the proximity.

[Burke]: We like being in the square.

[Burke]: So to that officer, thank you for opening up our eyes, because we really, we were not looking at this at that time.

[Burke]: So thank you.

[Burke]: And today would not have been possible without our DPW crew that put together everything that you see here in the last minute, as well as the Murphy brothers that provided the tenting for us.

[Burke]: So, you know, thank you.

[Burke]: It takes a village, and you guys are part of our village, and we really appreciate all the work you do.

[Burke]: And sometimes you're in the background, but we know you're there, and you're always trying to look out for our best interest.

[Burke]: So thank you to our whole DPW department for everything you do every day.

[Burke]: You know, Marion mentioned, D.A.

[Burke]: Ryan mentioned, that you call 911 and people come.

[Burke]: So we have our police that come, we have our fire that come, and a lot of times we have our DPW that come.

[Burke]: So they're an integral role in public safety in our community.

[Burke]: And before I turn it over to Jeff, I want to acknowledge our fire chief, Gil Birdy's in the building here.

[Burke]: Thank you, chief, for joining us today.

[Burke]: So without further ado, I'd like to introduce Jeff Shaw, our architect of record, to say a few words.

[Burke]: Thank you, Jeff.

[Burke]: And you do feel like a member of the family to all of us, so thank you.

[Burke]: I also want to acknowledge a few more department heads that are present with us today.

[Burke]: We have Aleesha Nunley-Benjamin, head of our finance department at City Hall.

[Burke]: Thank you, Alicia.

[Burke]: We have Michael Durham, our veterans agent who's here today.

[Burke]: Our superintendent of schools, Dr. Maurice-Edouard Vincent.

[Burke]: I think, have I missed any other department heads?

[Burke]: Our city engineer, Tim McGivern.

[Burke]: Tim, thank you.

[Burke]: And at this time, I would like to introduce the chief of police, John Jack Buckley.

[Burke]: Congratulations, you really are amazing and you are the heart and soul of this police department.

[Burke]: So thank you for everything you've done and being a part of this today.

[Burke]: At this time I'd like to invite Father Robert Casey to conclude the ceremony with a convocation.

[Burke]: Thank you everybody for joining us.

[Burke]: We're now going to kick it over there.

[Burke]: Item number two, report on upcoming MBTA road closures.

[Burke]: We have Mr. Terry McCarthy with us of the team, who has been the main point person for the GLX project in the city of Medford.

[Burke]: You notice he's wearing green.

[Burke]: He's a reason.

[Burke]: And I'm not the president of the team.

[Burke]: If I could, the chief has been extremely involved in this process.

[Burke]: I think pretty much weekly at this point they've been meeting with Todd Blake and Tim McGibbon, our engineer.

[Burke]: A lot of the streets that might be cut through now will have postings on them, and there will be officers at the other end enforcing it.

[Burke]: So a lot of the streets to the right of Main Street, I guess, if you were going to Somerville, a lot of them will be limited to just neighborhood traffic, so not cut-through traffic.

[Burke]: And then the schools, I know we moved a bus stop up a little farther up, a new crosswalk we put in.

[Burke]: So we can get a message out to the schools, but certainly the police are well informed.

[Burke]: I'm just wondering if I could well, I don't think we should even don't even worry about the dates right now I think it's the principle well for me, and I'm the pragmatist For me the question is saying hey the first date is March 14th who can make it do we have a subcommittee?

[Burke]: But we can't, in order to accomplish things we need to at least start that early or earlier.

[Burke]: Well, we have to review the schedules to see.

[Burke]: And the administrators to prepare the document, I would imagine.

[Burke]: It's going to take some time.

[Burke]: So I think right now, we should probably just take a vote whether or not we want a subcommittee or a committee of the whole.

[Burke]: And then we can just move on and try to schedule things.

[Burke]: Motion to create a committee of the whole to have these proposed- There's a motion on the floor that a committee of the whole be held to conduct these pre-budget hearings.

[Burke]: It may be earlier than 6, though.

[Burke]: It may have to be earlier than 6.

[Burke]: That's fine.

[Burke]: Of course.

[Burke]: There's a motion.

[Burke]: Okay, new business.

[Burke]: School committee resolutions.

[Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of William Bill Brady.

[Burke]: Mr. Brady was a member of the Medford School Committee for 25 years.

[Burke]: He was a tireless advocate for all aspects of education, and he will be missed in Medford.

[Burke]: Mr. Brady was the uncle of Medford math coach Ellie O'Leary.

[Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Elaine Torres.

[Burke]: Ms.

[Burke]: Torres was the wife of the late Angel Torres, who was a teacher and coach at Medford High School.

[Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Patrick Carr.

[Burke]: Mr. Carr was a Medford police detective for many years, and he was the husband of the late Shirley Carr, an administrative assistant at the Medford Vocational Technical High School.

[Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of Guadalupe Maturana.

[Burke]: Mrs. Maturana was the wife of the late Guy Maturana, who established the Spartans Youth Football League, which eventually became the Pop Warner Football, as well served as president of the North Medford Little League.

[Burke]: both of which he guided voluntarily for years.

[Burke]: Two of her sons, Craig and James, are in the Mustang Hall of Fame, and her son Alan is a member of the Medford Rotary Club.

[Burke]: Also, Adam is a member of our licensing commission.

[Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee express its sincere condolences to the family of James Hayden Downs, father of Andrew's middle school principal, Michael Downs.

[Burke]: Mr. Downs was a retired Vietnam veteran residing in Nashville, Tennessee.

[Burke]: If we could all please rise for a moment of silence.

[Burke]: School Committee Resolution.

[Burke]: Whereas, free public schools available to all students without exception are foundational to our democracy and are required by the state constitution.

[Burke]: And whereas, all of our students, no matter where they live, deserve high-quality public schools that teach the whole child and provide them with a rich school experience that addresses their academic, social, and emotional needs.

[Burke]: Whereas, the state's foundation budget formula, which determines state aid to each district, has been woefully out of date for years, thereby underfunding our districts by more than $1 billion a year for essential educational services.

[Burke]: And whereas, an updated foundation budget formula would bring Medford up to $4,134,000

[Burke]: $775 in additional state aid each year, allowing us to move closer to providing all students with the education to which they are entitled as residents of the Commonwealth.

[Burke]: And whereas the legislature failed to pass any foundation budget legislation in the last session, leaving districts, educators, and students without the funds necessary to support the schools our students deserve in every district in the state.

[Burke]: Therefore, be it resolved that the Medford School Committee urges the legislature

[Burke]: to approve and fully fund a new foundation budget formula and support the Education Promise Act as submitted by Senator Sonia Chang-Diaz on May 1, 2019.

[Burke]: And if I could add, the Senate docket number is 101.

[Burke]: It had not received a number, a bill number, but that is certainly a way to track it until it receives such.

[Burke]: I also want to just make note a couple of weeks ago I announced here that we were going to be fighting the fight and even at the Martin Luther King breakfast for the NAACP we stressed that really it's something we all have to be advocating for because certainly the districts across the commonwealth are being underfunded in general and then when you look at Medford in particular it hurts.

[Burke]: When I look at the cherry sheets I've got the governor's new cherry sheets for the upcoming year.

[Burke]: And while a little bit of Chapter 70, which is our unrestricted numbers, are going up by measly dollars, we're getting hit with another million dollars net for charter school spending for 424 students.

[Burke]: It's an average of about 16 grand a kid that's going out the door for the charter school students, and the average coming in the door with our 70

[Burke]: for our over 4,000 students are about a little over $1,000 that we're getting from the Commonwealth.

[Burke]: So there's a huge disparity.

[Burke]: It's a huge issue.

[Burke]: Senator Chang-Diaz's bill actually lifts everyone up.

[Burke]: It's not really creating animosity between the true publics and the true charters, but it's trying to raise everyone up.

[Burke]: And just as late as Friday,

[Burke]: A House representative offered a bill as well, similar to Senator Chang-Diaz's, with some nuances in it.

[Burke]: So there are three bills right now that are tracking in the legislature.

[Burke]: So we're going to keep abreast of them all.

[Burke]: I'll notify you as things change to let you know the impacts from each of them.

[Burke]: Senator Diaz's did not have a time number of years for implementation.

[Burke]: The governor had a five-year time that he was going to implement in small doses.

[Burke]: And likewise, the House version has a five-year commitment to it.

[Burke]: So there are a lot of differences between the three bills, and we're hoping that our Metro Mayors Coalition can put together some really good comparisons.

[Burke]: I've tried to sit down and determine what the differences mean, but it's very technical because they're amendments to the current bill, the current law.

[Burke]: So you have to read the current law alongside all the amendments to figure them all out.

[Burke]: So it's very complicated.

[Burke]: Foundation budget, Christine got blessed, is extremely complicated to understand.

[Burke]: Mr. Russo, did you want to comment?

[Burke]: That's a lot of money.

[Burke]: Versus seeing a negative $1 million monetary sheet, which is like, it's shocking.

[Burke]: Shocking.

[Burke]: It's shocking to continue to see that downward spiral every year.

[Burke]: So if we could send this to the governor, our state delegation.

[Burke]: and continue every couple of weeks.

[Burke]: I think we have to re-look at this and then send out blasts and get parents and all of our teachers.

[Burke]: This impacts teachers, parents, administrators across the board.

[Burke]: So we need everybody to be in on this fight collaboratively.

[Burke]: Very good.

[Burke]: Is there a motion on the floor, Mr. Russo, to accept this resolution, seconded by Ms.

[Burke]: Van der Kloot, maybe collectively, seconded by all?

[Burke]: Roll call vote, please.

[Burke]: Yes.

[Burke]: On a vote of six in the affirmative, one absent, motion passes.

[Burke]: And if you looked at the city of Medford over the last several years, when you net out what we get in Chapter 70, which is school funding against our charter school expenses, we're negative.

[Burke]: Every year we've been going down lower and lower.

[Burke]: So the state is contributing less and less to the school system.

[Burke]: And therefore, the property tax burden really is covering

[Burke]: I think 87% of our school costs are covered through the tax bills.

[Burke]: So it's a huge burden on us.

[Burke]: And then it's very disparate when you compare the urban-suburban.

[Burke]: And it's frustrating, because we really are educating the most vulnerable in the Commonwealth, similar to Boston.

[Burke]: Be it resolved that the Medford School Committee hereby approve a letter of support for pedestrian improvements near the Roberts Elementary School, Walk Medford, through the MassDOT Safe Routes to School grant.

[Burke]: There's a motion on the floor to approve.

[Burke]: As we know, parents, I believe, is there a parent?

[Burke]: And we've been very successful.

[Burke]: It's in the planning processes.

[Burke]: MassDOT pretty much takes over the whole process once it's approved.

[Burke]: And they've become the leader of it.

[Burke]: So they are working towards the Brooks School

[Burke]: completion as well.

[Burke]: We're going to circulate it after we take the vote and get signatures on it.

[Burke]: All right.

[Burke]: Okay, under new business, school committee resolution.

[Burke]: We at Resolve at the Medford School Committee express our sincere condolences to the family of John Welch.

[Burke]: Mr. Welch helped manage facilities at the La Conte Brink and was a teacher for 37 years in Somerville.

[Burke]: He will be missed.

[Burke]: If I could tell you the amount of people that attended his wake was amazing and the hockey players, the hockey team showed up and they all in their jerseys and

[Burke]: It was quite a tribute to him.

[Burke]: He was a wonderful man, and he had an impact on so many.

[Burke]: And he worked at Fenway for many, many years.

[Burke]: So if we could all rise and have a moment of silence on his passing.

[Burke]: Thank you.

[Burke]: And motion to adjourn.

[Burke]: If you'd all like to sit down.

[Burke]: Good evening clergy, elected officials, chiefs of police, friends and family of police chief-elect Jack Buckley, members of the Metro Police Department, and residents.

[Burke]: This evening we come together to witness the oath that will be taken shortly by our new police chief, Jack Buckley.

[Burke]: I am proud to be your mayor for this occasion.

[Burke]: First, I would like to share some historic facts

[Burke]: The official formation of the police department was on March 21, 1870.

[Burke]: Prior to that, dating back to the 1600s, they were known as peace officers.

[Burke]: According to Medford on the Mystic, the first full-time police chief was Jophannes H. Whitney, who was appointed on May 1, 1884 in the town of Medford.

[Burke]: The first chief to be named after becoming a city in 1892 was Emery D. Holmes.

[Burke]: He was paid an annual salary of $1,101.93.

[Burke]: Oddly, in a report presented on February 1, 1892 by Chief Holmes, he said, I would call your attention to the quarters of the police.

[Burke]: I will simply say that the present quarters are entirely inadequate.

[Burke]: The more things change, the more they stay the same.

[Burke]: There have been 10 police chiefs who have led the women and men of the Medford Police Department since beginning as a city.

[Burke]: These chiefs strived to make our city safer, build partnerships in the community, and to protect and serve the people of Medford.

[Burke]: Most recently, under the leadership of retired Chief Leo Sacco, we have made great strides in cultivating Medford as a welcoming community.

[Burke]: Thank you, Chief Sacco, for your collaboration, your selflessness, and your leadership.

[Burke]: So tonight, Lieutenant Buckley will join this illustrious group as our 11th permanent police chief.

[Burke]: I'd like to take a moment to speak about Jack's professional career within our department.

[Burke]: He joined the force in November 1998.

[Burke]: He was elevated to sergeant in May 2008 and later to permanent lieutenant in September of 2015.

[Burke]: His employment record is exemplary.

[Burke]: Over the course of my various roles within the city of Medford, I've had the opportunity to work with Jack.

[Burke]: He is articulate, polite, and well-versed in the subject matter at hand.

[Burke]: Throughout this appointment process, from the first time use of an assessment center to the group interview, Jack demonstrated composure under pressure, presented unique ideas, and a command of 21st century policing.

[Burke]: I was struck by what he thought was an accomplishment of his, that he was proud to be happily married after 20 years and an invested dad to Allison and Sarah.

[Burke]: Kudos, Jack.

[Burke]: All while serving 20 years on the force.

[Burke]: This example portrayed his human side and his humble side.

[Burke]: He also referenced that he is a man he is today due to his upbringing.

[Burke]: The moral compass his parents instilled in him, hard work and being ethical.

[Burke]: As President John F. Kennedy said, no responsibility of government is more fundamental than the responsibility of maintaining the highest standards of ethical behavior for those who conduct the public business.

[Burke]: And so, with pillar one of the 21st century policing being to build trust and legitimacy, who better to build upon Chief Sacco's legacy than a person who embraces ethics, respect, and trustworthiness?

[Burke]: As Jack said, law enforcement culture should embrace a guardian rather than a warrior mentality.

[Burke]: He also acknowledged that the police department does not reflect the proportionality of the makeup of the city of Medford.

[Burke]: He offered suggestions for augmenting participation in the civil service process for members of our minority community, and tonight I affirm that the mayor's office and chief will commit to offering minority candidates training sessions that will guide individuals through the exam process in order to ensure positive outcomes.

[Burke]: I concur with Chief Holmes stated back in 1892, the current police station is totally inadequate.

[Burke]: As chief, Jack will be tasked with overseeing the construction of the new police headquarters along with the team that we have assembled.

[Burke]: I am confident that he and all those who have and will work in this new headquarter will be extremely proud of the completed facility.

[Burke]: So in closing, I trust that our new chief will engage in our community through listening sessions.

[Burke]: I trust that our new chief will be a role model for the women and men of the Medford Police Department.

[Burke]: I trust that our new chief will implement the pillars of 21st century policing.

[Burke]: And I trust that our new chief will work hard every day to protect the rights of all.

[Burke]: And I trust that our chief will be a peace officer to the residents of Medford.

[Burke]: I am proud to serve with you, Jack Buckley, in this next chapter of your professional career as Chief of the Medford Police Department.

[Burke]: So at this time, I would like to invite Police Chief-Elect John D. Buckley, his wife Dawn and daughters Allison and Sarah up to the front rail, along with Chief Michael Golding of Weston, formerly of Medford, Massachusetts, who will administer the oath of office.

[Burke]: The meeting of the Medford School Committee will now come to order.

[Burke]: The Secretary will call the roll.

[Burke]: Mrs. DiBenedetto?

[Burke]: Present.

[Burke]: Present.

[Burke]: Mrs. Van De Koop?

[Burke]: Present.

[Burke]: in the Medford High School foyer.

[Burke]: While we're into suspension, Mr. Benedetto.

[Burke]: Name and address, please.

[Burke]: Thank you.

[Burke]: Mr. Russo.

[Burke]: Mr. Jerome?

[Burke]: I don't know if that's a good way to put it.

[Burke]: to our third graders, everyone gets a dictionary or whatnot.

[Burke]: So it's not really, their fundraiser isn't, like the PTO, everything they do is for this process.

[Burke]: Similar to Friends of Softball, that's strictly for Medford school, it's not for outside entities that can accept the gifts.

[Burke]: which became Medford Recreational Hockey.

[Burke]: Mr. Bailey was a senior custodian at Medford High School for many years.

[Burke]: Mr. Lynch was the father of Andrew's middle school guidance Councilor, Thomas Lynch.

[Burke]: Am I pronouncing it correctly?

[Burke]: Bertucci.

[Burke]: They performed a heroic act at Hampton Beach this summer in late August, and they basically saved a woman's life there.

[Burke]: So we had a wonderful presentation for these two young lads who were very humble.

[Burke]: And they just did an amazing thing.

[Burke]: And I think that they're just a very proud example of our students and how they stand tall and leadership skills that they are learning in the Medford school system.

[Burke]: And it goes to the teachers, administrators, and their families as well that have really instilled such great ethic in them.

[Burke]: So I just wanted everyone to be aware of that.

[Burke]: And it's just a wonderful thing that these two young men did on August 20.

[Burke]: Report on partnership with Lesley University.

[Burke]: Over the past several months, the City of Medford School Department primarily and Lesley University, high-ranking officials in Lesley University,

[Burke]: In addition, Bob Maloney, Mark Grumley, it's been kind of a full court press of meetings with this university.

[Burke]: What brought them to Medford was a desperate need for some athletic space, predominantly the wood floor.

[Burke]: They would like a wood floor at the high school.

[Burke]: and also tennis courts.

[Burke]: That's what brought them to Medford, but once they were in Medford, we realized how much more they can offer to this community.

[Burke]: I've been meeting with several organizations that try to train coaches and school systems in how to deal with trauma.

[Burke]: Leslie's training people to do that type of work.

[Burke]: So they have students that will be looking for internships and co-ops

[Burke]: to learn in the field how to be great teachers, how to be great... It's getting late.

[Burke]: How to be social workers, et cetera.

[Burke]: So we think it's a great idea to move forward with Lesley University.

[Burke]: The one contractual item would be for the use of the courts in the cages at Medford High School.

[Burke]: NCAA requires they be wood floors.

[Burke]: We do not obviously have wood floors right now.

[Burke]: So they would be making an investment in our cages to put in state-of-the-art wood floors, also the scoring mechanism.

[Burke]: What other things in the cages?

[Burke]: Painting, cleaning it, lighting, plus paying us a fee every year to basically rent the space through this partnership.

[Burke]: Duggar would go through the city side of things.

[Burke]: Right now they have a permit to use Duggar Park.

[Burke]: for their tennis courts, but they also would like to have a commitment going forward.

[Burke]: So we will be working with them on an agreement, and likewise, they will be making improvements to the tennis courts, which our high school team plays on.

[Burke]: That's their home courts.

[Burke]: So we look at it as a win-win opportunity.

[Burke]: We think

[Burke]: We wanted to speak to the school committee about it to get your thoughts, but we think it's really something very positive for the school system and to have that partnership with Lesley University for our students as well.

[Burke]: Hopefully it'll be a matriculation opportunity and we're just very excited about it.

[Burke]: So thank you for the time commitment you've put into this.

[Burke]: And last week we visited Boston.

[Burke]: So we spent a lot of time with Dr. Maurice as well as her cohorts.

[Burke]: and colleagues and we got to know her a little bit better as well.

[Burke]: So thank you for joining us today.

[Burke]: The plan is to do three different scenarios.

[Burke]: The first one has been provided to each of the finalists and they have prepared PowerPoints to present to us today and your discussion points.

[Burke]: And then following that we'll have two short on the fly kind of questions and answers just to finish this off.

[Burke]: Thank you.

[Burke]: Welcome.

[Burke]: Would you like me to read scenario one?

[Burke]: Parents have a choice as to which school they will select.

[Burke]: One school, the Andrews, attracts more selections

[Burke]: than that of the other schools in the blend.

[Burke]: The difference is significant, and the entry grade 6 level, 50 students, is the estimate of disparity.

[Burke]: Please find attached a report that was provided to the school committee on this topic.

[Burke]: What ideas would you suggest to address this situation?

[Burke]: So if we're currently in the month of May, and we, parents have selected which school they'd like their children to go to next year,

[Burke]: This process, I would imagine, would take some time.

[Burke]: So what would be your next steps for the September school year?

[Burke]: Mr. Benedetto?

[Burke]: Very good, thank you.

[Burke]: Okay, question number two.

[Burke]: It is 9.30 a.m.

[Burke]: and your elementary school is in session when it is reported to you by the principal that a water main break has caused a shutdown of all sinks, toilets, water fountains, and kitchen operations.

[Burke]: There is no clear estimate of how long it will take to clear the water main.

[Burke]: Most parents of your students are at work or at other activities.

[Burke]: How should you proceed?

[Burke]: What are your options?

[Burke]: Are there any follow-up questions for Sandy?

[Burke]: Can you follow up on that?

[Burke]: Okay.

[Burke]: Okay, final question.

[Burke]: You begin the school year 2018-19 with a good budget plan in place.

[Burke]: In October, you find out that state revenues are falling below projections and the governor plans to make nine seat cuts that will affect your expected funding sources.

[Burke]: The cuts to the special education circuit breaker and homeless transportation will leave you $250,000 short.

[Burke]: Also, there are two unexpected emergency building repairs that will require at least an additional $150,000.

[Burke]: What will you do to address these issues and maintain a balanced budget?

[Burke]: By the way, it is only October and you know other financial issues can arise throughout the year.

[Burke]: What options would you recommend?

[Burke]: We've seen 9C cuts, correct?

[Burke]: Are there any follow-up questions?

[Burke]: Thank you so much.

[Burke]: Those were great responses for impromptu questions.

[Burke]: We really appreciate the time and especially digging deeper into the statistics.

[Burke]: We know staffs don't tell the whole story of the child, so certainly in our trip to Boston, I think we gained a comfort level with how you do look after children in your district and how everything you do really is focused on them.

[Burke]: And, you know, we were really lucky to be able to spend that time with your

[Burke]: your partners here.

[Burke]: I guess just one last question.

[Burke]: If you were selected superintendent, obviously we'll be working on a budget over the next, you know, through the end of the year, and you'd be inheriting that to a degree, so what is your availability to be in our community while you were finishing off Boston?

[Burke]: As you can tell, we're missing two members.

[Burke]: One planned, I'm not quite sure on the system.

[Burke]: In respect of them, we will have a committee of the whole meeting Monday evening.

[Burke]: What is it, 5?

[Burke]: 6.15, we scheduled before.

[Burke]: And then we will discuss the two candidates and hopefully we will be reaching a decision that evening.

[Burke]: Thank you so much.

[Burke]: Thank you so much for joining us.

[Burke]: It's not coming through.

[Burke]: Welcome back to Medford.

[Burke]: I know you got to spend the day with Central Office and our various principals and teachers the other day, so I hope that that went well.

[Burke]: And we're pretty much at the same format.

[Burke]: I can re-read the question if you'd like.

[Burke]: There are two middle schools in our city.

[Burke]: Both schools have essentially the same curriculum and staffing levels.

[Burke]: Parents have choice as to which school they will select.

[Burke]: One school, King Andrews, attracts more selections than the other, the McGlynn.

[Burke]: The difference is significant at the entry grade sixth level.

[Burke]: 50 students is the estimate.

[Burke]: Please find the task force report that was provided to the school committee on this topic.

[Burke]: What ideas would you suggest to address the situation?

[Burke]: Thank you.

[Burke]: Thank you very much.

[Burke]: We're going to now move on to two additional questions.

[Burke]: I'll read the first one.

[Burke]: The building emergency.

[Burke]: It's 9.30 a.m.

[Burke]: and your elementary school is in session, but it's reported to you by the principal that a water main break has caused a shutdown of all sinks, toilets, water fountains, and kitchen operations.

[Burke]: There's no clear estimate how long it will take to repeat a water main.

[Burke]: Most parents of your students are at work or other activities.

[Burke]: How should you proceed?

[Burke]: What are your options?

[Burke]: Mr. Vendetta?

[Burke]: You begin the school year of 2018-19 with a good budget plan in place.

[Burke]: In October, you find out that the state revenues are falling with the low projections and the governor plans to make 90 cuts that will affect your expensive funding sources.

[Burke]: The cost of the special ed circuit breaker and homeless transportation will leave you $250,000 short.

[Burke]: Also, there are two unexpected emergency building repairs that will require at least an additional $150,000.

[Burke]: What will you do to address these issues and maintain a balanced budget?

[Burke]: And by the way, it is only October and you know other financial issues can arise throughout the year.

[Burke]: What options would you recommend?

[Burke]: My follow-up question.

[Burke]: Well, I think we're in a bit of a transition right now.

[Burke]: Clearly, the next few months we need to get through budget negotiations with our teachers union and other unions.

[Burke]: So there's a lot of work that has to take place to just solidify the base.

[Burke]: But I think one of the largest obstacles, which someone could also look at as

[Burke]: Something welcoming is the open positions that we will be filling.

[Burke]: So it certainly is an opportunity to create a new way of looking at things and a new energy level, I think, in the community.

[Burke]: So that could be an opportunity, but it is going to be a struggle to get qualified candidates to fill these positions that have been held by people with long tenure here.

[Burke]: I'd say that's one of our obstacles we're facing.

[Burke]: Very good.

[Burke]: Well, thank you so much.

[Burke]: It was a pleasure visiting your community of Lexington and really getting to know the people that you work with.

[Burke]: They all spoke very highly of you, certainly have high aspirations for you.

[Burke]: So you have a lot of support in your current environment.

[Burke]: So we thank you for investing in us and we'll be in touch shortly.

[Burke]: Thank you.

[Burke]: Meeting of the Medford School Committee will now come to order for the second round of public interviews in our superintendent search.

[Burke]: I've been asked by the committee just to explain a few procedures.

[Burke]: I believe it's the collectively we will finish our interviews tonight.

[Burke]: We will be meeting on Monday, and we will determine whether or not we want to proceed with site visits of the candidates that are selected.

[Burke]: It could be limited.

[Burke]: We will make that determination on Monday night.

[Burke]: Committee of the Whole, Minutes from November 27th, 2017.

[Burke]: This was a meeting that we held last week in order to discuss the succession plan for our superintendent of schools.

[Burke]: We had the Mass.

[Burke]: Association of School Committees present.

[Burke]: He presented quite a brochure to us on strategies that we should use in our deliberations.

[Burke]: Ultimately, the Medford School Committee voted on the following matters in Committee of the Whole.

[Burke]: that the MASC, Mass Associated School Committee, will provide a sample brochure to us.

[Burke]: The school committee will also explore other search consultants before making a selection.

[Burke]: The school committee voted to review internal candidates first.

[Burke]: That was a 7-0 vote.

[Burke]: And the school committee voted to meet again on December 11, 2017 to continue its work.

[Burke]: We also had quite a bit of discussion around a search committee if we ultimately do go outside.

[Burke]: What was explained to us is if we do internal candidates,

[Burke]: It would be school committee interviewing in a public session.

[Burke]: If from there we go to a full search, a nationwide search, let's say, we would form a committee.

[Burke]: And the complement of that committee would be set up of three teachers from the different levels of schooling, one administrator, one student, school committee members, suggested was three, and also community members being parents.

[Burke]: And we also wanted to make sure that we included all subgroups such as special ed and ELL in those check boxes.

[Burke]: So we're working on an actual application.

[Burke]: For those out there, we're working on a formal application that people can fill out and submit back to us if they have an interest.

[Burke]: Also, I ask that our diversity director be a member of this committee.

[Burke]: It was voted on in seven to zero.

[Burke]: So thank you all for that.

[Burke]: And we will be meeting next week to discuss this further on December 11th.

[Burke]: Report on Community Preservation Act.

[Burke]: We have members of the committee, the CPC committee.

[Burke]: As you may realize, a year and a half ago, the citizens of Medford voted to adopt the CPA Act, which allows for monies to be put in a trust fund and spent for certain purposes, affordable housing, open space, and historic preservation.

[Burke]: And we have with us two members tonight that would like to explain it so that the public can become more aware of this program.

[Burke]: We have Joan Sear a member and Roberta Cameron is the chairperson of the committee.

[Burke]: I remember so many times seeing you gathering signatures to make sure that this would happen.

[Burke]: I would love to see that here.

[Burke]: We already have oil and grass.

[Burke]: are there any other recommendations they have been meeting with a lot of boards and commissions they've met with myself a lot of the department heads at City Hall

[Burke]: Lauren DiLorenzo with OCD about the open space plan.

[Burke]: This committee has worked so diligently and put in so many hours so that they really listen to the community.

[Burke]: It's almost like participatory budgeting to a degree where this is driven by the citizens as opposed to us up here driving it down.

[Burke]: So that's what's unique about this.

[Burke]: It's really coming from people.

[Burke]: Thank you.

[Burke]: Yes, thank you.

[Burke]: And then they make recommendations to the city council.

[Burke]: Very good.

[Burke]: Hello, my name is Stephanie Muccini-Burke.

[Burke]: I'm the mayor of Medford, Mass., home of the mighty Medford Mustangs.

[Burke]: They say up here in Medford country that our veins bleed blue and white, and we know you're the same.

[Burke]: We're here to support you in rebuilding your community.

[Burke]: I'm here with our athletic director, Bobby Maloney, and our head baseball coach, Mike Nestor.

[Burke]: Bobby, would you like to say a few words?

[Burke]: Michael.

[Burke]: Mustang Strong!

[Burke]: We support you.

[Burke]: Go Mustangs!

[Burke]: Good afternoon.

[Burke]: Our community has come together to raise awareness and join in the fight against pediatric cancer.

[Burke]: I'm buzzing my hair for kids with cancer.

[Burke]: I'm buzzing my head for kids with cancer.

[Burke]: I am going to spend it with my sister and my whole family.

[Burke]: We're going to eat lots of turkey and stuff it.

[Burke]: Thank you all for being here today and thanks to Billy Honeycutt, our favorite alumni for hosting us today.

[Burke]: I graduated with this guy and his wife Sue.

[Burke]: So even though we're not on the Malden line, we're really in Medford, the heart of Medford here.

[Burke]: But I want to wish you all a great Thanksgiving Day.

[Burke]: Good luck out on the field.

[Burke]: we'd want to bring the trophy home, but you know, it's more to be good sportsmen on that day.

[Burke]: So it's all about that and camaraderie.

[Burke]: You look around the room, you see what Malden and Metro have made of, and we're a great two cities.

[Burke]: We've got a great history, second oldest rivalry, contiguous rivalry going on here.

[Burke]: So keep it going, represent your cities well, and I look forward to seeing y'all more in the very near future, probably tomorrow at the Metropolitan.

[Burke]: We'll be out there at the

[Burke]: big event, the big event tomorrow.

[Burke]: So go get them, have fun, and enjoy your Thanksgiving holidays.
